Lots of things going on in my life. You know how sometimes God uses hard times to make you aware of just how selfish and proud and self-sufficient you are? Yeah, well, that's where I am right now. But as I've read through Job, I've been reminded that the suffering God allows us to go through is such a paradoxical demonstration of His love. It shows us that we need Him. And if we didn't realize how much we need Him, we would never know the blessedness of being totally dependent on Him.

Lord, I know You see this fear in my heart
of what my future holds.
I feel You softly ask if I can trust You more
and give you control.
So I kneel before You now and I offer everything.
Come and be the Lord of all--all I am or ever hope to be.

I surrender. I surrender to the One who loves me more than life.
I surrender. I surrender. Here is my heart. I open it wide.
To the one who cannot be unfaithful I now offer You all that I am.
I surrender. I surrender. From this day on, I'll be in Your hands.

I've been living for myself and now I want to live for You alone.
Come and help me when I'm weak and when my path seems so unknown.
You will be beside me still. I know You want what's best for me.
So when I want to take control, Lord, please come and help my unbelief.

I surrender. I surrender to the One who loves me more than life.
I surrender. I surrender. Here is my heart. I open it wide.
To the one who cannot be unfaithful I now offer You all that I am.
I surrender. I surrender. From this day on, I'll be in Your hands.

If you think of me, please pray that I would cling to Him.

I've been putting a lot of thought into getting involved the LiveJournal world again. A lot of the reason I switched to Xanga is because I get annoyed with the way LiveJournal works. But I'm going to come back again--at least for awhile, for a couple of reasons. 1) I've been missing some of my friends that only use LJ. 2) I have some things I need to get out, and Xanga is not the place to do it. I've been thinking through a lot of things and learning a lot, and I feel the need to express it, but I don't feel like it would be wise to be that open on Xanga since so many people access my Xanga blog. So anyway, just to let you know what's going on....

Most likely I will protect my posts here and make them friends only. If you want to read my posts, you're going to have to respond to this post. Anyone who doesn't respond will be removed from my friends list.

And just so you're prepared for what's coming, I really do plan on using my LJ as a place to bare my soul, to some extent. I feel like there are some things I need to sort out and won't be able to unless I share them. So bear with me, please. I'm really not looking for your criticism. I'm going to be transparent here. I want to make sure everyone knows a lot of the things I want to say are things I'm still sorting out myself, and I don't claim to necessarily be right. I just want to try to sort through some of my confusion by writing it out. I do welcome your input, though.

The main thing I want to talk about is the issue of love. I turn 23 tomorrow (happy birthday to me!) and, to be perfectly honest, I never thought I would still be single at 23. In some ways I am at peace with it. I know God is doing the best for me. But at the same time, I'm lonely. And it hurts to see friends all around me, most of them younger than I, getting together and getting married. There are all kinds of emotions that well up inside of me. And because of my nature, I have to get them out. That's what I want to do here. I have so many questions about love, and I want to understand as much as I can. Some of the questions I have I want to discuss on here the next few posts, such as:

-How do I reconcile being satisfied in God and yet anticipating "fulfillment" in a mate? Is it possible to long for and miss someone I don't know and yet still see God as the Lover of my soul?
-How do I have a realistic and yet romantic view of love? When I hear married people continually tell me "marriage is not all its cracked up to be" am I supposed to just accept that? Or is there really a way to be in love for a lifetime? How can I be determined to stay in love and yet have a realistic expectation of the trials that are part of every relationship?
-What's with all these people that seem like they get into a relationship just to have someone? How do I really feel about getting married because I'm "in love with love" vs. getting married because I find someone I "can't live without."
-Is love paradoxical? It seems that love hurts so bad, yet in the midst of all the hurt is also healing. How will I have the courage to take a risk, to lay my heart on the line, and to pledge my entire life to someone?

So that's what this journal is going to be--at least for awhile. Hopefully in talking out my confused thoughts I'll find the clarity I'm looking for.

Keep on running,
Farther, faster
Keep on searching,
For this haunting has an answer.

I am so in love with Arbonne's concealer. It comes in a little pot and it's awesome. So when I logged onto Arbonne's site the other day and found out they are discontinuing it, I was bummed. They're going to introduce another product, which will most likely be even better, but I was worried that I might run out before the new one is available. So I called Jenni. Me: When are they going to come out with the new concealer? Jenni: I'm not sure. Me: Well, I need to know, because I don't want to run out of my pot before I can get some new, 'cause I'm tellin' ya...I'm really addicted to that pot. :shocked: I'm serious, it was out before I realized how it sounded. :laughing: So, yeah, as I was saying the other day, my new job is so cool. I'm working full time at 2BC and I have been working my booty off. It's been so fun, though. I'm the main person in charge of graphic design and publications. I'm also assisting the music ministers, which means preparing the digital presentations for worship services and assisting them with whatever odd jobs they need done. There are a couple of reasons why my job is so fun: 1. My responsibilities--To someone who loves graphic design, there's nothing more fun than having someone come in and say, "Can you make me a poster advertisement for this?" and then turn you loose. 2BC has a plotter where I can print out huge posters, and that has been so fun. I also love multimedia, so getting to put together PowerPoint presentations for worship services and adding video...very fun. This is just my forte. 2. The people I work with--The atmosphere in the 2BC office is awesome. The office is run professionally, but people are also flexible. Everyone has fun working there. The relationships between staff members are good. Everyone is grateful and treat each other with respect. I am enjoying getting to know the staff there. It is really obvious that God has placed me there, and it's amazing to see how He is blessing me for stepping out in faith. I just happened to drop a resume off at the office because I was passing by. I almost didn't leave one there, because I didn't figure they would need someone. I didn't know that they had just been told the lady who previously held my job was leaving. They hadn't even started looking for someone when I dropped off my resume. Imagine my surprise when I got called for an interview and then offered an awesome job! It has really shown me that God's grace is more than abundant, and that He desires to bless our lives and give us His best. But often that place of blessing comes from giving up things that are very close to your heart. You have to just close your eyes, climb on the side of the boat, and take that flying leap into the waters of faith. And, like Peter, you feel the force of the water and suddenly realize that you are indeed walking in it...and staring into the loving, beautiful eyes of your Master. And then you wonder why it took you so long to jump in the first place.

Notice: Very important post. -- After winning a bronze medal in the 2004 Olympics in Athens, wrestler Rulon Gardner took off hhis shoes, placed them in the center of the mat, and walked away in tears. Through that symbolic act, Gardner announced his retirement from the sport which had defined his life for many years. Times of walking away come to all of us, and they can be emotionally wrenching. A loved one "walks away" in death. A child moves away from home. We leave a job or a community and it feels as if we've left everything behind. But when we know the Lord, we never have to walk into an unknown future alone. It's worth pausing to reflect on how much the children of Israel walked away from when Moses led them out of Egypt. They left the heavy burden of slavery, but they also left everything stable and predictable they had ever known. Later, when the Lord told Moses, "My Presence will go with you, and I will give you rest" (Ex. 33:14), Moses replied, "If Your presence does not go with us, do not bring us up from here" (v.15). During our most difficult times, our stability comes from the presence and peace of God. Because He goes with us, we can walk into the future with confidence. -David McCasland (Taken from the August 10, 2005 devotional Our Daily Bread) -- After much prayer and seeking the Lord through His Word, He's made it very clear that it's time for me to walk away, looking ahead to something new He is doing in my life. I have accepted a full time publications job at Second Baptist Church and my mom and I will be attending Woodland Heights Baptist Church. Our family has been very blessed by the ministry and fellowship we've found at Grace Bible, but God has clearly told us He wants to do something new in our lives. As a Christian, our lives are to be used for the glory of God, and when He says "go" we must obey. My heart is full of amazement at the way God has worked to make this change possible and to give the grace to pursue His will with all my heart. He has given me an incredible excitement about what He is going to do as I obey Him. Like Peter, I've taken a flying leap into the waters of faith and it's awesome to see God performing miracles for His glory. Peace and joy have flooded my soul to know I am obeying God and seeing His blessing. But at the same time, I want all of my friends at Grace to understand that it tears my heart out to leave. To walk away from everything that has been dear to me the last seven years is heart wrenching. I want you to know that you have had an incredible impact on my life and I love you all more than I could ever express. I pray that we will not forget each other, but continue to spur one another on to love and good works in Christ. May God's grace and peace be yours in abundance. I am about to do a brand new thing. See, I have already begun! Do you not see it? (Is. 43:19, NLT)

I was so excited to find this GREAT bag to package it in: I had the greatest time making Bri a "Vote For Pedro" shirt (thanks to Paul for the instructions--lol). The only problem is that after I made it I wanted it for myself. The fun bag and fun gift made for a fun night. But the best thing about the evening was talking with so many great people. I got to see a bunch of friends I hadn't seen in a long time: Lance, Candyce, Summer, Kinz, Spence, Bethany, Ashley, Grace, or "Dopiopi" as I like to call her, and Mollie. Enjoyed quoting Napoleon with Grace and Mollie, getting long-overdue hugs from Spence, and also having a super great talk with Audie. Such was the case tonight, meeting Jordan, Sean, Ethan and David. Jordan, it was so great to finally meet you. Love you, bro. Ethan, it was fun laughing about addressing people by their screen names in real life ("Hey...sheepyshocka, right?"). Sean, though we didn't say much more than "hi," it was good to meet you and I hope to get to know you better in the future. David, it was awesome discussing our testimonies, evangelism, salvation, and just life in general. Can't wait to meet your wonderful wife and kids. And I am so grateful for your example of a Christ-centered marriage and your obvious love for your wife. I love people. I loved tonight, because I was with people...people who love God and want to please Him. I thank God in all my remembrance of you...It is only right for me to feel this way about you, because I have you in my heart, since...you all are partakers of grace with me. (Phil. 1:3-7). Thank you to my wonderful friends...you are grace to me. -- As I promised Michiko, one of the most awesome people in this world, the next few days I will be posting some of my beliefs about romantic relationships--courtship and dating, the emotional purity movement, etc. For some reason unbeknownst to me, people want to know my thoughts on the subject. *shrug* Anyway, they are coming, so hang tight...probably tomorrow. And just as a warning, they may not be what you expect. MWAHAHA.

CHILDHOOD MEMORY #4 -- "In His Time" One of my earliest memories is of my mom putting me to bed each night. She would snuggle me or kneel beside my bed until I drifted off to sleep. Sometimes she would pray or just talk to me. But the main thing I remember is the songs she would sing. They always calmed and comforted me. Beautiful, beautiful, Jesus is beautiful, And Jesus makes beautiful things of my life. Carefully touching me, causing my eyes to see That Jesus makes beautiful things of my life. and... In His time, in His time, He makes all things beautiful in His time Lord, please show me every day As You're teaching me Your way, That You do just what You say in Your time. In Your time, in Your time, You make all things beautiful in Your time Lord, my life to you I bring, May each song I have to sing Be to You a lovely thing in Your time. I'm sure Mom would never have guessed that twenty years later those songs would still bring me comfort. As an adult, I don't rely on the simple choruses to lull me to sleep each night, but they often provide a soothing balm to a tired heart. When my heart grows weary with waiting, tired of seeing friends all around me fall in love and get married, of experiencing disappointment, of watching passing days turn into passing years waiting for the one that I will someday give myself to completely...then I am drawn to these songs once again. When I was a baby, Mom sang those words to put me to sleep; today I sing them often to myself as a reminder to hope in God's perfect timing. He makes even the barren wastleland of waiting beautiful...in His time.

You know those days when you're so rotten you can hardly stand to live with yourself? Well, that was my day. I started out this morning praying that I would be filled with the Spirit and that the fruits of His Spirit would abound in my life. Unfortunately, I'm afraid that, as a whole, my attitudes and actions today produced the opposite affect. *sigh* But, thankfully, God's grace is sufficient for even my especially rotten days, and right now I'm rejoicing in His forgiveness. In spite of the bad day caused by my bad attitude, I was enjoying the spring weather immensely. I loved getting to wear my flips and the new skirt I made for Easter. Fun stuff! Ah, how I love flip flop weather. Picture below for anyone who cares: The great weather permitted me to enjoy a good bike ride. It might not have been one of those forty-something mile dudes that a lot of you do every day, but it was enough to burn off some calories and get my heart rate up. One of my best friends called while I was out riding and we had a fun chat. But I kept thinking it must've looked funny to passers by to see me riding along, steering with one hand, talking on my cell with the other. Well, seeing as how I am sitting here with my eyes closing against my will, I supposed I'd better record my next memory and go spend some quality time with my pillow. -- CHILDHOOD MEMORY #3 -- "Early Memories--Camping Among the Giant Sequoias and Visiting Disneyland" I was blessed to be born in the beautiful state of California. It seems that before I was born, camping trips to the Giant Sequoias were a regular occurrence in our family. For some reason, after I arrived that all stopped. My family will tell you this is a fact which causes me frustration even decades later (man, I feel old when I say that!). When my family sits around and starts talking about their camping experiences and how breathtaking the giant trees were, I always feel strangely left out and deprived. Thankfully for them, one of my earliest memories does involve camping among the goliath trees. I vaguely remember being afraid of bears, and wanting to stay very close to Mommy and Daddy. And I do remember that the trees were very, very big. But then, when you're 3, everything seems big. Another of my earliest memories will be etched upon my memory until I am at least one hundred and two, to be sure. No child born in California should be denied a fun-filled day at Disneyland! So they whisked me off to Anaheim before I was old enough to say "Micky Mouse." All throughout the day they pumped me up for a special show we were going to see called "The Bear Country Jamboree," which basically consisted of a bunch of stuffed bears that supposedly sang and danced to the delight of all present in the audience. All was fine until they lowered a girl bear on a swing and she began swinging to and fro. Panic gripped my tiny little heart as it suddenly dawned on me that this was no innocent, entertaining show--no, this bear was rapidly swinging toward me, closer and closer. Yes, this bear was after me! In amonst all the clapping and laughing of the audience, a screaming three-year-old's voice could be heard. My voice got louder and louder until finally my dad took pity on the rest and, disappointed, took me outside to calm me down. It's a good thing they didn't take me into the Haunted Mansion! ;-)

Well, I'm back. Back to my beloved coffee pot and internet connection (even though it is dial-up). And for those of you who have been wondering, I've finally proved to you that it's possible. Yes, I can be offline for several days and still be perfectly happy. Usually when we go to Oklahoma, I get on Becky's computer to check e-mails and Xanga and stuff. But when I got there this weekend, their montior had been zapped by lightening or something. Thus leaving me "disconnected" for three days. I could've gone through the trouble of configuring my laptop with their ISP settings, but I didn't feel like it. Anyway, I had a great weekend playing with Aidan. (And seeing my bro-in-law and sis was great, too, of course). We decorated eggs, went to a party, rented a movie, talked late into the night, and Nathan and I played old Atari video games. Before we left, I had bought a skirt pattern and fabric to make a new skirt for Easter. So we worked on that this weekend, and got it all ready for this morning. It it so cute. But some things happened and we ended up not going to church this morning, so I still haven't worn it yet. Mom and I read about the crucifixion and resurrection on the way home. I love the part where Jesus is walking with the men along the road to Emmaus. "Didn't our hearts burn within us as He told us about the scriptures?" Ah, that's good stuff. Some pictures from the weekend. -- CHILDHOOD MEMORY #2 -- "Before I Can Remember--Special Toys, First Word, and a Rather Strange Nickname" Obviously, I couldn't remember the first couple years of my childhood. But I have been told that I loved my tootle train. It seems I also got immense enjoyment out of carrying around a *bucket of peanut butter. Most kids first learn how to say "Mama" or "Dada," but no, my first word was "tickle," which alerted the family early on that I was going to be a very different sort of child. I also had the habit of wrinkling up my nose in a cute manner and making a sort of snorting sound. Supposedly it was very cute, and it earned me the nickname of "Snorterine" from my sister Beth. When arriving home from school, she would open the front door and begin to call "Snorter...Snorterine!" until she found me. Back then, it was cute, but let's just say I don't giggle and drool when she does it now. -- *Does anyone remember when the peanut butter came in those buckets? They had handles and dinosaurs on the outsides?

Everyone in the entire world needs to read this post. -- Today has been such a Mia Thermopolis kind of day. It would normally be my day off, but I'm at work. Not only that, but I've been given an article for the newsletter that's a nightmare to lay out. I am about to go crazy. I left my coffee and half and half sitting on the kitchen cabinet. There was this really good topic on the LL forum about waiting on God, and it appears that after triple posting on it, I messed the whole thing up and now it's gone into the dark black hole of forumdom. And Meg won't give me a candybar. Ah, well...life goes on. Tomorrow I'll be cuddling my nephew and all my worries will be out the door. I came home so burdened last night after Bible study. We had a great study, discussed all kinds of topics. I ate tons of olives. We looked at the Wills' pictures from Florida. Ann and I talked 80's talk ("bodacious, dude").... There's something in my extroverted personality that I get around people and start joking around and my troubles are out the door. But when I got in the car, all the burdens came back. On the way home, my mom told me something that just added to my confusion about where God is taking me. I was restless all night. I got to IM Esther for awhile, and she e-mailed me some song lyrics that encouraged me. I went into my mom's room, and she called me to her. I knelt by her bed, and she laid her hand on my head. I wept as she prayed for me, then went back to my room to do some weeping and praying of my own. Thanks to those of you who are lifting me up before the throne of grace. I can't explain what I'm going through right now, but I know that as God leads me, I'm going to have to step out on faith. My heart is so full--I'm so excited about what God is doing, and yet I am scared of it at the same time. I'll stop trying to explain it, because I can't.... Last Saturday, I spent the day helping my mom mow the lawn and clean out our shed. I came across some diaries and stories I had written as a child. It was so fun to read over them and reminisce about my childhood. I started thinking about how I want to record memories from all throughout my life to look back on later. I think it would be fun. I remember as a child ALWAYS begging my mom to tell me stories of "when she was a kid," so it would be fun to have memories to pass on to my children. So, anyway, when I update, I'm going to start adding a childhood memory to each post. Please don't feel obligated to read them, but just to let you know, they're gonna be there. -- MEMORY #1 -- MY LIFE BEGINS, AND OUR FAMILY FINALLY LEARNS THE MEANING OF THE WORD "CUTE" I was the only baby my parents planned. My mom had three daughters before me, all of which are very intelligent. Marcie is very smart, social, and witty. She has a lot of skills in organizing and she is very practical. Beth is a genius. Ask her any question, no matter how obscure, and she will be able to tell you the answer. She knows how to do everything from quilting to raising chickens...and she does it extremely well. Rebecca is artistic. From a young age, she drew with amazing skill. She was crafty in more ways than one--she could also design clothes. Yes, my sisters are very intelligent. And they had lots of skills. Well, as we know, guys only like girlfriends who have great skills, which is probably why I am still single at the ripe old age of 22. It seems that after having three very intelligent and skillful daughters, Mom and Dad said, "Enough with all this intelligence! We need a kid that's cute in this family!" Thus, I was conceived. A couple months before I was born, my dad's mother died. All I have to remember my grandmother by is a bunch of crazy stories my family has told me and a lamp of her's that was given to me. As my family was still grieving over the loss of my grandma, I was born. A beautiful new life to comfort after the loss of another. So...out I came. "My, how cute!" my family exclaimed in delight. True, I had a mop of black hair. True, I had a crooked nose, but they knew this was gonna be one cute child. My mom had always been partial to the name Amanda, which somehow morphed into Mandy as time passed on. My 8-year-old sister Rebecca was given the responsibility of choosing my middle name. I won't repeat it here, but let's just say it's not one of my favorite names in the universe. It seems it is the job of the youngest child to just be cute. And so I have done, most pleasantly, I must say. Why, just the other day my mom said to me, "You know? We spend entirely too much time talking about how cute you are." I disagreed. It's actually a pretty tough job...but, you know, somebody's gotta do it.

I watched Joan of Arc last night and cried all the way through it. It really hit me how one woman's courage and faith breathed hope and determination into an entire nation. Her life inspired men to take a stand for freedom. As inspring as her life was, however, it was her death that gave Frenchmen the courage to reunite their country. When the English burned her at the stake, it was not only a punishment to her, but a warning sign to the French. But instead of scaring them, it had the opposite effect. It gave them courage. And seven years later, France was free.

The same thing happened with William Wallace. As he united the clans to restore Scotland to independence, he faced tremendous persecution. When he was finally captured by England, he was doomed to a torturous death. After disemboweling him, they beheaded and quartered him. His arms and legs were sent to the corners of the country and his head was mounted on London Bridge to frighten Scots who would dare to even consider continuing the fight for their freedom. But Wallace's death inspired Scottish warriors to carry on his banner. Not many years later, Scotland became independant under the command of Robert the Bruce.

As I sat in Perspectives tonight and heard of missionaries who were giving their lives to take the Gospel to the world, I thought of Wallace, and I thought of the maiden Joan...and I was ashamed. Sure, I can proclaim that I love God until I'm blue in the face, but when it comes right down to it, do my actions show it? Do I show that freedom in Christ is not only worth living for, but worth dying for? And when I see others who are giving their lives for the Gospel, does it spur me on? Does it ignite a fire of courage in my soul? Or does it reveal that I am a coward?

God has been doing so much in my life the last few months, it awes me. I'm ashamed to admit it, but after going thorugh some painful situations last year, my walk with God became very lukewarm. Sadly, my prayer life suffered greatly. Thankfully, God showed me just how apathetic I had grown toward Him, and I realized I was not striving to be satisfied in Him.

I have always struggled with my prayer life, but during this "spiritually low" time, it seemed as if prayer was almost non-existent. It was awful. But, praise God, I finally realized several months ago that I needed to get my booty in gear and earnestly seek Him. Lately, I have been energetically praying for God to make me a woman of prayer. To think, infite joy in His presence is offered to me, and I pass it up for fleeting pleasures. Lately I have been struck with the reality of God's amazing, transforming mercy. He turned Saul into Paul. He turned John, the "son of thunder," to the "apostle of love." I long for that kind of powerful transformation in my prayer life. And, slowly, but surely, God is doing it. He has resotred to me the joy of my salvation, and I am finding delight in His presence once more.

I have been learning so much about prayer, and I hardly know how to express it all. But one of the biggest things God has done has shown me the privilege of prayer. It has dawned on me just how much it cost the Son of God for me to enter into His presence with boldness. I would not be able to come before His throne were it not for the incredible forgiveness offered me by God when Christ became sin for me. His agonizing death on the cross is what gives me, a filthy sinner, the ability to come before the holy, spotless Lamb of God. So when I am treating prayer as a chore, rather than a privilege and delight, I am trampling on the blood of Christ. I am spitting in His bloody face. God, may I never take Your shed blood lightly!

In Thy presence is fullness of joy; at Thy right hand there are pleasures forever. -Psalm 16:11

I had a few people over last night for a party, and Jacob was kind enough to bring his Incredibles DVD for us to watch. That special features DVD is a riot! We were rolling on the floor laughing at some of it. A couple people stayed really late to watch the special features, and it was a good time. Functioning on very little sleep, I woke up this morning, got ready, and went to work. My day at the office was pretty busy, as I'm still trying to get all my software installed and preferences set from the OS upgrade. Enjoyed talking with Jenni a couple times during the day (Jenno, you're the best). At lunch time, we went to the Oak Street Bistro for lunch with Susan and her mom. Susan and I used to go to the Bistro every week when she was helping out at the office, so it's a tradition. It's a very sentimental place for us to go. Anyway, we were delighted to find out they have added their White Cheddar Dill (the best soup in this entire world) to their everyday menu. We went outside and took a few pictures. My new profile picture was one of them. Here's the other: I love my Susan, I do. After my whirlwind day at the office, I ran home, got freshened up, came back into town and met Elise, Rachel, Ross, and Reid for a trip to Little Rock. We were going to see Arkansas Christian Academy perform The Sound of Music. Bri, one of my favoritest people in this entire world, was playing in the orchestra, so I wanted to see her. She did a great job, as did the other musicians and actors/actresses. Lotsa talent in that group of high schoolers, I'll tell ya what! Got to visit with Bri for awhile and we took a quick photo: Love, love, love your glasses, Bri. I also FINALLY got to meet DT, inventor of "What the cow?!". That was pretty cool, bro.To make things even greater, I was reunited with an old friend, St_Lucia, whom I have not seen in a long time--and I even caught a glimpse of her Sir Knight. On the way home, Elise and I goofed off the entire time and weirded the Riggans out real bad. It was fun. But alas! all good things must come to an end. And so I will make my way to my bed to spend some quality time with my pillow. I bid you a so long, farewell, auf wiedersehen adieu, whatever that means.

Musha ring dum a doo dum a da Whack for my daddy-o Whack for my daddy-o There's root beer in the jar-o I'm in the midst of preparing for a big St. Paddy's Day "spraoi," at my house tonight, complete with a lot of good food and music. It's gonna be a wild time, and tons of fun. It's going to bring those dance-a-jig type Irish sentiments. But right now as I am sitting here relaxing before the big party, I have more of a melancholy Irish sentiment. Words can't express the emotion that grips me today. I'm tearful. I cry for for Irish ancestors that perished in the great famine of 1846-47. I cry as I picture them reaching down into the earth to pull up a potato--their only source of food--and finding instead slimy rot. I cry for them watching their loved ones die of terrible diseases and seeing the few that survived turn into living skeletons. I cry for them having to drink the blood of their animals to survive. I cry to think of them having to watch the land that was once their own being controlled by their enemies, of seeing their land provide bountiful supply of grains and vegetables and watching these foods be exported to other countries right in front of their starving eyes. I cry to think of them being evicted from their homes as they were literally rotting away, some of them having their homes torn down on top of them as they were fighting for their lives. I cry to think of the Irish leaving their beloved homeland to journey to America, the isle of hope. Their poverty forced them to do so. When they left Ireland, they knew they would never see it again, never again would they see the faces of the ones they loved so dearly. And when they reached America many of them were met with hatred and scorn. I cry to think of the Irish who fought courageously in our own Civil War and perished on the battlefield. I cry over the incredible emotion of the Irish people. Their love is so deep. Their courage is so valiant. Their sorrow is so heart-wrenching. I cry as I think of St. Patrick, and the terrible things he endured as he was taken from his home off the coast of Scotland and forced into slavery in Ireland. I cry as I see God's mercy in saving him and giving Patrick a passion for Him as he spend many lonely hours as a shepherd on those green hills. I cry as I think of how he escaped and traveled home--in the safety of his home he dreamed of the people of Ireland crying out, "We beseech thee, come and walk among us again!" I cry as I think of how he went back to the very people who had enslaved him and devoted his life to giving them the truth of the Gospel. I cry as I think of the thousands of people who came to know Christ through his ministry. And last of all, I cry for Ireland as it is today. So many people who need Christ--people who have been turned off from Protestant Christianity because of the torture their ancestors had to endure from the Protestant English. People who are so rooted in tradition that they will not listen to the truth. This is the land that I love. This is the land that I pray for. How I wish every sould on that Emerlad Isle to understand the Gospel of Christ. Oh, Erin gra mo chri, you're the dear old land to me! You're the fairest that my eyes have ever known. You're the land St. Patrick blessed, you're the bright star of the West! You're my own native land so far away!

Don't you just love those times when you're reading your Bible and God gives you a passage so powerful that it just blows you away? That happened to me yesterday. I had come face to face with my selfishness and I was crying out to God to meet with me and give me mercy that I would love others. I opened my Bible to John 13. Here's what I saw: Jesus was having supper with His disciples. But this supper with them was different--it would be His last. He was about to be killed. He was about to be betrayed by Judas. He was about to be denied by Peter. And yet in an act of humility and servanthood He rose from the table, took a basin and towel, and began to wash the feet of His disciples. Peter was appalled: "Lord, You're washing my feet!" I can see the look on Peter's face like he's thinking What is up with this?! Hello! You're God! I'm man! I should be washing Your feet! Jesus continued to wash his feet, explaining that later Peter would understand His reasons. But in hypocrical false humilty Peter announced, "Never! You should never wash my feet!" Jesus tenderly replied, "Peter, if You don't let me do this, you can't have any part of Me." Peter's attitude changed as he surrendered, "Lord, not only my feet, but also my hands and my head." Jesus began to explain to his disciples that though they all might appear clean, not all of them were. He said this because He knew He was about to be betrayed. The amazing part? He knowingly washed the feet of His betrayer. The spotless, holy Lamb of God humbled Himself to serve the one who was about to give Him up to be killed. After He finished washing their feet, Jesus looked at them and said, "Do you know what I just did? Do you understand that I, your Master and Lord, just washed your feet?" As the humbling truth sunk in, Jesus revealed one of the reasons for this act of servanthood: "If I, being holy, washed your sinful, unholy feet, how much more should you wash each other's feet?" Can you imagine the shocked silence? Jesus just leveled the field. All of a sudden it was clear that they were all equally sinful. Quit exalting yourself above each other He was saying. You're all sinners. But if I served sinners, how much more should you sinners be willing to lay aside your pride and serve each other? The last few days I've been asking myself the question, What part of my reputation am I holding on to? We all have certain things that make up our identity.

For some, it's power.
For some, it's influence.
For some, it's purity.
For some, it's being a missionary, evangelist, pastor, or counselor.
For some, it's participating in ministry opportunities.
For some, it's a strong prayer life.
For some, it's talent.
For some, it's a good sense of humor.
For some, it's high standards in music, entertainment, dress, or relationships with the opposite sex.

Whatever it is, we all have an identity. We all have a reputation that we want to grasp, to cling to. If someone attacks our identity, we feel crushed and rise up in defensiveness. Whether we actually do it or not, we feel like yelling Don't touch my reputation! This is an area of strength for me! This is an area where I please God and serve others! Back off!

Your attitude should be the same that Christ Jesus had. [I]Though He was God, He did not demand and cling to his rights as God. He laid aside His reputation, took aside the humble position of a slave and appeared in human form. And in human form He obediently humbled himself even futher by dying a criminal's death on a cross" (Phil. 2:5-8)

Christ's also had an identity. He had a reputation--He was God. But instead of grasping that reputation, He cast it aside. He lowered Himself to be a slave to sinners who would mock and hate Him. And as the sinful, idiotic, stupid humans like you and me spit on Him and questioned His identity, He just humbled Himself even more and died to offer us forgiveness.

And we are supposed to imitate that example. In comparison, our reputation is insignificant. We may live pure lives, have high standards, have spiritual disciplines, and spread the gospel to the world, but none of us has the identity that Christ had. None of us is God. If Christ gave up His reputation, why do we so often see ours as something to cling to?

Rather, honoring God is an end in itself and a means of avoiding regret." "Of all arguments again love none makes so strong an appeal to my nature as 'Careful! This might lead to suffering.' To my nature, my temperment, yes. Not to my conscience. When I respond to that appeal I seem to myself to be a thousand miles away from Christ. If I am sure of anything I am sure that His teaching was never meant to confirm my congenital preference for safe investments and limited liabilities. I doubt whether there is anything in me that pleases Him less... Even if it were granted that insurances against heart-break were our highest wisdom, does God Himself offer them? Apparently not. I believe that the most lawless and inordinate loves are less contrary to God's will that a self-invited and self-protective lovelessness... Christ did not teach and suffer that we might become, even in the natural loves, more careful of our own happiness. If a man is not uncalculating towards the earthly beloveds whom he has seen, he is none the more likely to be so towards God whom he has not. We shall draw nearer to God, not by trying to avoid the sufferings inherent in all loves, but by accepting them and offering them to Him; throwing away all defensive armour. The past year has been pretty tough for me relationship-wise. (Not complaining, just sharing.) My relationships have done a complete switch for the most part. I am grateful though, for those friends who always seem to be there. When I think about the friends who are just always there, and the other friends who seem to come and go, I think a lot about what makes a true friend. And I pray that God would make me this kind of friend to people I know. I've been thinking about what makes good relationships the past couple of days, and keep trying to remind myself of these points:

1. True friends are lovingly honest. They will tell you the truth about matters, but then leave it up to you to make a decision. 
2. True friends are trustworthy. They don't talk about you behind your back, even when everyone else is.
3. True friends don't let you make foolish mistakes without speaking up. They express concern when they see you heading toward the edge of a cliff. True friends also listen when you express concern. They are not defensive; they want to hear what you have to say.
4. True friends share you with other friends. They don't see you as someone to keep all to themselves. They don't act possessive.
5. True friends don't pressure you. Your friendship has freedom.
6. True friends don't demand you to conform to their ideas and standards. They trust your judgement. They also don't ask you to conform to their interests, but are glad to see you be your own person.
7. True friends don't bail out when trouble comes. Instead, they stand by your side and support you through the stuff of life, even if it is inconvenient for them.
8. True friends are not afraid of each other.
9. True friends depend on God first, and then on each other.
10. True friends admit their weaknesses to you and don't put on an act of having it all together. 
11. True friends change their behavior when you tell them they've hurt you. They don't just let it end in an apology--they take action to correct the problem.
12. True friends work through problems in a relationship rather than avoiding them.
13. True friends earn trust, rather than demanding it.
14. True friends are concerned about "we" more than they are about "I."
15. True friends encourage freedom. They do not hold onto you as if you're a dependant child...they are excited to see you be a separate person.
16. True friends confront honestly in love rather than flattering you.
17. True friends are consistant, their friendship doesn't fade over time.
18. True friends forgive rather than condemn.
19. True friends are a positive influence on your life and spur you on to love and good deeds.

Today has been very emotional for me. It seemed like one thing after another happened that made me want to burst into tears. Usually I would do that but with the house full of people right now it is somewhat difficult. One thing that was very painful was when my family went to visit my dad's grave. I go there often, and of course it is always emotional, but today was even more so because we were all together. My mom, sister Marcie and her family, Beth, and I all there. I was just remembering some of those times in the past when Dad was around, and wishing he could be with us still. You know, I have told my mom many times that I will be happy if my marriage is half as good as hers. My dad was not a spiritual leader in our home, and in fact I am not even sure he was a Christian. I DO want to marry someone who is a spiritual leader--more than anything. But I also want to marry someone I am head over heels in love with, and he with me. That's the way Mom and Dad were. He adored her, and she him. I remember him coming home from work every day and immediately looking her up for a kiss. "Honey, I'm home!" he would yell. He wolf-whistled at her all the time and praised her in front of his children. Growing up, when I went to friends' homes where there was a lot of fighting in the house I would come home depressed and confused. Why? Well, our home wasn't like that. In fact, it was so rare for Mom and Dad to have a fight that when they did, it scared the life out of me. They snuggled up next to each other when in the car, and Mom used to take me to town during Dad's lunch break so we could hang out with him for half an hour. They loved to be around each other, even after all those years of being married. As I've been thinking about this kind of love lately, it just suddenly hit me that that's how marriage is meant to be. We're fed so many lies nowadays about how being in love is only a phase and passes once you're married for awhile. I'm glad to be able to say that I know that's not true...I know because I've seen that theory proven wrong. And the other night, it floored me when I felt God remind me, "That's how I want it to be for you." It so stunned me that I went to my mom in tears and said, "Mom, God wants me to be cherished by someone!" Somewhere God has someone for me who will love me for who I am. And when I find him, I don't think I'll be able to resist falling head over heels. People have asked me if I'm making any New Year's Resolutions. I don't usually make resolutions, but each year I do have one thing in mind, I want to learn how to love others. At each year's end, I look back and ask myself, Have I learned unconditional love more this year? Is my love more Christ-like now than it was last year? So this year I do have a goal of learning to love more like Christ does. Sometimes I get so sick and tired of having to deal with a lot of hard relationships. I get tired of all the misunderstandings and rumors and rejections and changes and disappointments. But through the pain of it all, I have to remind myself, This is what I asked for. This is what is teaching me to love.

Today I have been downloading commercials from the 80's. flutewoman3's recent entry about an 80's party reminded me of a website I came across awhile bak that had archived commercials from the 80's. So I have had a fun time watching some old commercials from when I was a kid. Along the same lines, yesterday I took a trip down memory lane. I ran to the post office, and was feeling the need to spend some time alone in prayer. So I drove around for awhile. I drove past the houses in the area where we used to live, and remembered days gone by. -The house where we once accidentally set off hundreds of bottle rockets at my birthday party--kids running in every direction and screaming--nevertheless a fun memory -My best friend's house across the street, where we spent hours playing Barbies (or I would desert her for Cops 'n Robbers and Hot Wheels when her brother was around) -The shack (no joke) where a little boy lived that came and played Zorro with me -The home of a bully--I used to threaten to put on my cowboy boots and stomp on his toes if he didn't leave me alone -The creek where I just swore I saw an alligator one time -The house of the neighbor boy I had a crush on And I could go on and on...good times. I also stopped at the cemetery where my dad was buried. I love to go to the cemetery. After I spend awhile at my dad's grave, I enjoy just looking around at the tombstones, reflecting over each life that was lost. There's a mother and her newbotn daughter--they must have died during childbirth. There's a sister and brother who died on the same day--was it an awful accident? There's a military man--he probably served in WWII! I also always notice the graves of husbands or wives, and notice that when one dies, many times the spouse follows shortly after. That is another reminder to me of how strong true love really is. Many times the pain of separation is so great that the spouse honestly can't live without the other. It also reminds me of the shortness of life. Like it says in Isaiah, our lives are a passing vapor. None of us is guaranteed tomorrow. As I wandered throughout the graves, and thought about the uncertainty of life, I prayed to God that I would make my life count for something. I don't want to waste it away on frivilous pursuits--each moment should count for eternity. As one man's tombstone so wisely stated: One life to live That soon will pass, Only what's done For Christ will last.
